article.description: Florida found its focus just in time.
article.headline: Gators, now 9-2, overcome 10-point deficit in first half

images.name: Hamilton_Justin 021223 inline
images.caption: It took a while, but Justin Hamilton (12) and the Florida Gators were able to pull away from Charleston Southern. Hamilton had 13 points.

article.linkText: No. 13 Florida has to rally to beat Charleston Southern
article.story: GAINESVILLE, Fla. (AP) -- Florida found its focus just in time. Matt Bonner scored 17 points and Anthony Roberson added 16 as the Gators (No. 13 ESPN/USA Today; No. 12 Associated Press) overcame a 10-point first-half deficit to beat Charleston Southern 74-62 Monday. ''Probably for the most part, they outplayed us,'' Florida coach Billy Donovan said. ''I was happy with the win. But at the same point, we are not a basketball team that can just show up and play. We really need to come with great focus in order to be good. We're not good when do what we did today.'' The Gators (9-2) have won 34 consecutive games at home against non-conference opponents. Kevin Warzynski had 16 points to lead Charleston Southern (4-4), which has lost three in a row. The Buccaneers also lost at Michigan (84-53) and Tennessee (63-49). ''It was a tough stretch for us and we were hopeful that we could continue to become more competitive,'' Charleston Southern coach Jim Platt said. ''I thought we took another step forward today. That was a good basketball game from start to finish.'' With the score tied, Florida went on a 10-2 run to go ahead 64-56 with four minutes left. Bonner and Roberson hit jumpers, and Brett Nelson added a fastbreak layup. ''Mentally, our guys weren't there for about 30 minutes,'' Donovan said. ''I think we had eight minutes in the second half where we played really intense.'' The Buccaneers opened the second half with a 9-3 run to build its lead to 41-33 with 16:23 left. ''I knew coming in here that we would be very much challenged,'' Donovan said. ''I know there are terms such as 'cupcake,' but I knew that was not going to happen based on watching film on Charleston Southern.'' Roberson hit two 3-pointers during a 10-2 run that tied the game at 43-43. The Buccaneers scored the next six points, but Florida ran off seven in a row to go ahead 50-49 with 10:47 to play. ''I was not going to let my team go down,'' Roberson said. ''I was going to go down fighting. We didn't play that good in the first half, but I didn't want to lose.'' Florida, which had one day off after beating Miami 94-93 in double overtime Saturday, fell behind 30-20 with five minutes left in the first half. Gene Granger made two transition layups during Charleston Southern's 9-0 run. ''Fatigue, for me, was an issue,'' Bonner said. ''But it wasn't physical, it was mental coming off an emotional double-overtime game. That's my fault. I'm a senior. That shouldn't happen. I wasn't as focused as I should have been.'' Roberson and Bonner each made a 3-pointer during an 8-0 run for Florida, which trailed 32-30 at halftime. During a first-half timeout, Donovan slammed his clipboard to the floor. ''I was upset with them,'' Donovan said. ''My thing right now is, if they come focused and prepared and play together as a team, then we have a chance to be special. If you don't play that way, we're average.'' The game was the 200th at Florida for Donovan, who is 133-67.

venue.fullName: Exactech Arena at Stephen C. O'Connell Center
